assessment_metadata.purpose: IRT-based ability estimation for adaptive learning path
assessment_metadata.instructions: Complete all 30 questions in one sitting. Cannot go back to previous questions.

ASSESS_PHY_MECH_001.subject: Physics
ASSESS_PHY_MECH_001.question_text: A block of mass 5 kg is placed on a horizontal surface. A force of 20 N is applied at an angle of 30° above the horizontal. If the coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and surface is 0.2, what is the acceleration of the block? (Take g = 10 m/s²)
ASSESS_PHY_MECH_001.question_text_html: A block of mass 5 kg is placed on a horizontal surface. A force of 20 N is applied at an angle of 30° above the horizontal. If the coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and surface is 0.2, what is the acceleration of the block? (Take g = 10 m/s²)
ASSESS_PHY_MECH_001.solution_text: Horizontal component of force: F_x = 20cos30° = 17.32 N. Vertical component: F_y = 20sin30° = 10 N. Normal force: N = mg - F_y = 50 - 10 = 40 N. Friction: f = μN = 0.2 × 40 = 8 N. Net force: F_net = 17.32 - 8 = 9.32 N. Acceleration: a = F_net/m = 9.32/5 ≈ 2.0 m/s²

solution_steps.formula: F_x = Fcos θ, F_y = Fsin θ
solution_steps.explanation: Break the 20 N force into horizontal and vertical components
Vertical equilibrium: Normal force balances weight minus vertical component of applied force
Net horizontal force divided by mass gives acceleration

common_mistakes: Forgetting to subtract vertical component from normal force
metadata.hint: First resolve the applied force, then calculate normal force considering vertical component
metadata.key_insight: Tests understanding of force resolution, friction, and Newton's second law in combination
metadata.elimination_strategy: Rough estimate: If no friction, a ≈ 17/5 ≈ 3.4 m/s². With friction, must be less. Eliminates D.

distractor_analysis.C: Forgot friction or wrong friction value
distractor_analysis.D: Used full 20 N without resolving components

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Excellent MCQ: 4 options, 7 concepts, strong distractors

ASSESS_PHY_MECH_002.subject: Physics
ASSESS_PHY_MECH_002.question_text: A particle of mass 2 kg moves from rest under a constant force. If it travels 20 m in 4 seconds, find the power delivered by the force at t = 4 seconds. Express your answer in Watts.
ASSESS_PHY_MECH_002.question_text_html: A particle of mass 2 kg moves from rest under a constant force. If it travels 20 m in 4 seconds, find the power delivered by the force at t = 4 seconds. Express your answer in Watts.
ASSESS_PHY_MECH_002.solution_text: Using s = ½at², we get 20 = ½a(16), so a = 2.5 m/s². Force F = ma = 2 × 2.5 = 5 N. Velocity at t=4s: v = at = 2.5 × 4 = 10 m/s. Power P = Fv = 5 × 10 = 50 W

solution_steps.explanation: Particle starts from rest, so use s = ½at²
Power is force times velocity at that instant

ASSESS_PHY_MECH_002.jee_pattern: Multi-concept numerical combining kinematics and power

metadata.formula_used: s = ½at², F = ma, P = Fv
common_mistakes: Using average power instead of instantaneous
metadata.hint: First find acceleration from displacement-time data, then force, then velocity, finally power
metadata.key_insight: Tests integration of kinematics, dynamics, and power concepts

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Multi-step numerical: 4 steps, 6 concepts

ASSESS_PHY_MECH_003.subject: Physics
ASSESS_PHY_MECH_003.question_text: A uniform disc of mass 4 kg and radius 0.5 m is rotating at 10 rad/s about its center. A point mass of 1 kg is gently placed at the edge of the disc. What will be the new angular velocity? (Moment of inertia of disc = ½MR²)
ASSESS_PHY_MECH_003.question_text_html: A uniform disc of mass 4 kg and radius 0.5 m is rotating at 10 rad/s about its center. A point mass of 1 kg is gently placed at the edge of the disc. What will be the new angular velocity? (Moment of inertia of disc = ½MR²)
ASSESS_PHY_MECH_003.solution_text: Initial angular momentum: L₁ = I₁ω₁ = (½ × 4 × 0.25) × 10 = 5 kg·m²/s. Final moment of inertia: I₂ = ½MR² + mR² = 0.5 + 0.25 = 0.75 kg·m². By conservation: ω₂ = L₁/I₂ = 5/0.75 = 6.67 rad/s

solution_steps.explanation: Moment of inertia of disc about its center
Angular momentum before mass is added
Angular momentum is conserved when no external torque acts

ASSESS_PHY_MECH_003.validation_notes: Gemini validated. Corrected answer from C to A (6.7 rad/s)

metadata.formula_used: L = Iω, I_disc = ½MR², I_point = mR²
common_mistakes: Forgetting to add point mass MI
Not using conservation of angular momentum
metadata.hint: Angular momentum is conserved. Calculate before and after moments of inertia
metadata.key_insight: High discrimination - tests moment of inertia concepts and conservation laws
metadata.elimination_strategy: Adding mass increases I, so ω must decrease. Original is 10, so answer must be less. Eliminates nothing directly, but guides calculation check.

ASSESS_PHY_MECH_003.image_description: Top view of a circular disc rotating about its center axis. A point mass is shown at the edge of the disc. Arrows indicate rotation direction.
ASSESS_PHY_MECH_003.image_alt_text: Rotating disc with point mass at edge
ASSESS_PHY_MECH_003.diagram_code_python: import matplotlib.pyplot as plt; import matplotlib.patches as patches; import numpy as np; fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1, figsize=(8, 6)); ax.set_xlim(-1.5, 1.5); ax.set_ylim(-1.5, 1.5); ax.set_aspect('equal'); circle = patches.Circle((0, 0), 0.5, linewidth=2, edgecolor='#6B46C1', facecolor='#E9D5FF', alpha=0.3); ax.add_patch(circle); ax.plot([0], [0], 'ko', markersize=8, label='Center'); ax.plot([0.5], [0], 'ro', markersize=12, label='Point mass (1 kg)'); ax.arrow(0, 0, 0.45, 0, head_width=0.08, head_length=0.05, fc='#6B46C1', ec='#6B46C1', linewidth=2); ax.text(0.25, 0.15, 'R = 0.5 m', fontsize=12, color='#6B46C1', fontweight='bold'); ax.arrow(0.3, 0.4, 0.15, 0.15, head_width=0.06, head_length=0.04, fc='#D946EF', ec='#D946EF', linewidth=2); ax.text(0.35, 0.55, 'ω', fontsize=16, color='#D946EF', fontweight='bold'); ax.text(0, -1.2, 'Rotating Disc (M = 4 kg)', fontsize=12, ha='center', fontweight='bold'); ax.grid(True, alpha=0.3, linestyle='--'); ax.legend(loc='upper left', fontsize=10); ax.set_xlabel('x (m)', fontsize=11); ax.set_ylabel('y (m)', fontsize=11); ax.set_title('Uniform Disc with Point Mass at Edge', fontsize=13, fontweight='bold', pad=15); plt.tight_layout(); plt.savefig('output.svg', format='svg', bbox_inches='tight'); plt.close()

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Excellent MCQ: 4 options, 6 concepts, strong distractors

ASSESS_PHY_MECH_004.subject: Physics
ASSESS_PHY_MECH_004.question_text: A ball of mass 0.5 kg moving at 20 m/s collides head-on with a ball of mass 1.5 kg moving at 10 m/s in the opposite direction. If the collision is perfectly elastic, find the velocity of the 0.5 kg ball after collision (taking the initial direction of 0.5 kg ball as positive). Express your answer in m/s.
ASSESS_PHY_MECH_004.question_text_html: A ball of mass 0.5 kg moving at 20 m/s collides head-on with a ball of mass 1.5 kg moving at 10 m/s in the opposite direction. If the collision is perfectly elastic, find the velocity of the 0.5 kg ball after collision (taking the initial direction of 0.5 kg ball as positive). Express your answer in m/s.
ASSESS_PHY_MECH_004.solution_text: For elastic collision: v₁ = [(m₁-m₂)u₁ + 2m₂u₂]/(m₁+m₂) = [(0.5-1.5)×20 + 2×1.5×(-10)]/(2) = [-20-30]/2 = -25 m/s. Negative sign indicates reversal of direction.

solution_steps.description: Identify given values with sign convention
solution_steps.calculation: m₁ = 0.5 kg, u₁ = +20 m/s, m₂ = 1.5 kg, u₂ = -10 m/s
solution_steps.explanation: Second ball moves in opposite direction, so u₂ is negative

solution_steps.description: Apply elastic collision formula for first body

solution_steps.explanation: Negative indicates ball bounces back in opposite direction

ASSESS_PHY_MECH_004.jee_pattern: Standard elastic collision with head-on approach

common_mistakes: Forgetting negative sign for opposite direction
metadata.hint: Assign proper signs based on direction. Second ball moves opposite to first, so its velocity is negative
metadata.key_insight: Tests understanding of elastic collision and vector sign conventions

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Multi-step numerical: 4 steps, 1 concepts

ASSESS_PHY_ELEC_001.subject: Physics
ASSESS_PHY_ELEC_001.question_text: Three capacitors of capacitances 2 μF, 3 μF, and 6 μF are connected in series across a 120 V battery. What is the charge stored on the 3 μF capacitor?
ASSESS_PHY_ELEC_001.question_text_html: Three capacitors of capacitances 2 μF, 3 μF, and 6 μF are connected in series across a 120 V battery. What is the charge stored on the 3 μF capacitor?
ASSESS_PHY_ELEC_001.solution_text: For series: 1/C_eq = 1/2 + 1/3 + 1/6 = (3+2+1)/6 = 1. So C_eq = 1 μF. Total charge Q = C_eq × V = 1 × 120 = 120 μC. In series, all capacitors have the same charge, so Q₃μF = 120 μC

solution_steps.explanation: In series connection, all capacitors store same charge

ASSESS_PHY_ELEC_001.jee_pattern: Standard capacitor series problem - high discrimination

metadata.hint: Key property: In series, all capacitors have the SAME charge
metadata.key_insight: High discrimination - tests understanding of series capacitor property vs parallel
metadata.elimination_strategy: If using Q = CV for individual capacitor, would get 3×40=120 or 3×60=180, helping narrow choices

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Excellent MCQ: 4 options, 3 concepts, strong distractors

ASSESS_PHY_ELEC_002.subject: Physics
ASSESS_PHY_ELEC_002.question_text: Two point charges +4 μC and -4 μC are placed 6 cm apart. Find the electric potential at the midpoint of the line joining them (in Volts). Take k = 9 × 10⁹ N·m²/C².
ASSESS_PHY_ELEC_002.question_text_html: Two point charges +4 μC and -4 μC are placed 6 cm apart. Find the electric potential at the midpoint of the line joining them (in Volts). Take k = 9 × 10⁹ N·m²/C².
ASSESS_PHY_ELEC_002.solution_text: At midpoint, distance from each charge = 3 cm = 0.03 m. V = k[q₁/r + q₂/r] = k[(4×10⁻⁶/0.03) + (-4×10⁻⁶/0.03)] = 0 V (potentials cancel due to equal and opposite charges)

solution_steps.description: Find distance from midpoint to each charge
solution_steps.explanation: Midpoint is equidistant from both charges

solution_steps.description: Calculate potential due to positive charge
Calculate potential due to negative charge

solution_steps.explanation: Potentials are scalar quantities and add algebraically

common_mistakes: Calculating electric field instead of potential
Forgetting negative sign on negative charge
Not recognizing symmetry leading to zero
metadata.hint: This is an electric dipole. At the midpoint (perpendicular bisector), potentials from equal and opposite charges cancel
metadata.key_insight: Tests understanding that potential is scalar and dipole creates zero potential at center

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Multi-step numerical: 4 steps, 3 concepts

ASSESS_PHY_CURR_001.subject: Physics
ASSESS_PHY_CURR_001.question_text: In a circuit, three resistors of 2Ω, 3Ω, and 6Ω are connected such that the 2Ω and 3Ω resistors are in series, and this combination is in parallel with the 6Ω resistor. If a 10V battery is connected across this network, what is the total current drawn from the battery?
ASSESS_PHY_CURR_001.question_text_html: In a circuit, three resistors of 2Ω, 3Ω, and 6Ω are connected such that the 2Ω and 3Ω resistors are in series, and this combination is in parallel with the 6Ω resistor. If a 10V battery is connected across this network, what is the total current drawn from the battery?

solution_steps.description: Calculate equivalent resistance of parallel combination

metadata.hint: First combine series resistors, then find parallel combination with remaining resistor
metadata.key_insight: Tests systematic circuit reduction and fraction manipulation
metadata.elimination_strategy: Rough: If all in series, R=11Ω, I≈0.9A. If all parallel, R≈1Ω, I≈10A. Answer must be in between, closer to parallel. Eliminates A being too low.

distractor_analysis.A: Used wrong parallel formula or calculation error

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Excellent MCQ: 4 options, 3 concepts, strong distractors

ASSESS_PHY_MAG_001.subject: Physics
ASSESS_PHY_MAG_001.question_text: An electron moving with velocity 2 × 10⁶ m/s enters a uniform magnetic field of 0.5 T at right angles. Find the radius of the circular path in millimeters (mm). Take e = 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C, m_e = 9.1 × 10⁻³¹ kg.
ASSESS_PHY_MAG_001.question_text_html: An electron moving with velocity 2 × 10⁶ m/s enters a uniform magnetic field of 0.5 T at right angles. Find the radius of the circular path in millimeters (mm). Take e = 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C, m_e = 9.1 × 10⁻³¹ kg.

solution_steps.description: Identify the formula for radius of circular motion
solution_steps.explanation: For charged particle in magnetic field, centripetal force equals Lorentz force

solution_steps.description: Calculate radius and convert to mm

ASSESS_PHY_MAG_001.jee_pattern: Standard charged particle motion in magnetic field

metadata.hint: Use formula r = mv/(qB). Careful with scientific notation and unit conversion to mm
metadata.key_insight: Tests application of Lorentz force and numerical accuracy with small values

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Multi-step numerical: 4 steps, 2 concepts

ASSESS_PHY_EMI_001.subject: Physics
ASSESS_PHY_EMI_001.question_text: A rectangular coil of 50 turns with area 0.1 m² is placed perpendicular to a magnetic field. If the field changes uniformly from 0.2 T to 0.8 T in 0.3 seconds, what is the magnitude of induced EMF?
ASSESS_PHY_EMI_001.question_text_html: A rectangular coil of 50 turns with area 0.1 m² is placed perpendicular to a magnetic field. If the field changes uniformly from 0.2 T to 0.8 T in 0.3 seconds, what is the magnitude of induced EMF?

solution_steps.description: Calculate rate of change of magnetic field
Calculate rate of change of flux
solution_steps.explanation: Flux = BA, coil perpendicular to field

common_mistakes: Forgetting the number of turns N
Not taking absolute value for magnitude
metadata.hint: Use Faraday's law: ε = N × A × (dB/dt). Calculate rate of change of B first
metadata.key_insight: Tests understanding of Faraday's law with changing magnetic field

distractor_analysis.C: Used wrong time or field change

ASSESS_PHY_EMI_001.image_description: Rectangular coil with 50 turns shown perpendicular to magnetic field lines. Arrows indicate field direction. Labels show area = 0.1 m², B changes from 0.2T to 0.8T.
ASSESS_PHY_EMI_001.image_alt_text: Rectangular coil in changing magnetic field
ASSESS_PHY_EMI_001.diagram_code_python: import matplotlib.pyplot as plt; import matplotlib.patches as patches; import numpy as np; fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1, figsize=(8, 6)); ax.set_xlim(-0.5, 3.5); ax.set_ylim(-0.5, 2.8); ax.set_aspect('equal'); rect = patches.Rectangle((0.5, 0.5), 2, 1.5, linewidth=3, edgecolor='#6B46C1', facecolor='none'); ax.add_patch(rect); ax.text(1.5, 1.25, '50 turns', fontsize=11, ha='center', fontweight='bold', color='#6B46C1'); ax.text(1.5, 0.9, 'A = 0.1 m²', fontsize=10, ha='center', color='#6B46C1'); [ax.arrow(i, -0.3, 0, 0.4, head_width=0.08, head_length=0.08, fc='#D946EF', ec='#D946EF', linewidth=1.5, alpha=0.7) for i in np.linspace(-0.3, 3.3, 15)]; [ax.arrow(i, 2.2, 0, 0.4, head_width=0.08, head_length=0.08, fc='#D946EF', ec='#D946EF', linewidth=1.5, alpha=0.7) for i in np.linspace(-0.3, 3.3, 15)]; ax.text(-0.3, 1.25, 'B field', fontsize=12, rotation=90, va='center', fontweight='bold', color='#D946EF'); ax.text(3.5, 2.0, 'B: 0.2 T → 0.8 T', fontsize=10, bbox=dict(boxstyle='round', facecolor='#FDE68A', alpha=0.8)); ax.text(3.5, 1.6, 'Δt = 0.3 s', fontsize=10, bbox=dict(boxstyle='round', facecolor='#FDE68A', alpha=0.8)); ax.arrow(2.7, 1.25, 0.3, 0, head_width=0.1, head_length=0.08, fc='red', ec='red', linewidth=2); ax.text(3.2, 1.35, 'EMF', fontsize=14, color='red', fontweight='bold'); ax.axis('off'); ax.set_title('Rectangular Coil in Changing Magnetic Field', fontsize=13, fontweight='bold', pad=15); plt.tight_layout(); plt.savefig('output.svg', format='svg', bbox_inches='tight'); plt.close()

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Excellent MCQ: 4 options, 3 concepts, strong distractors

ASSESS_PHY_MOD_001.subject: Physics
ASSESS_PHY_MOD_001.question_text: Light of wavelength 400 nm is incident on a metal surface with work function 2.0 eV. What is the maximum kinetic energy of the emitted photoelectrons? (Take h = 6.63 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s, c = 3 × 10⁸ m/s, 1 eV = 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ J)
ASSESS_PHY_MOD_001.question_text_html: Light of wavelength 400 nm is incident on a metal surface with work function 2.0 eV. What is the maximum kinetic energy of the emitted photoelectrons? (Take h = 6.63 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s, c = 3 × 10⁸ m/s, 1 eV = 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ J)

solution_steps.explanation: Convert from Joules to electron volts
Energy of photon minus work function gives maximum kinetic energy

common_mistakes: Using wrong wavelength units (nm to m)
Adding work function instead of subtracting
metadata.hint: First calculate photon energy in eV, then subtract work function
metadata.key_insight: Tests understanding of photoelectric effect and careful unit management
metadata.elimination_strategy: Photon energy ≈ 3 eV, work function = 2 eV, so KE must be around 1 eV. Eliminates C and D.

distractor_analysis.C: Wrong subtraction or unit conversion error
distractor_analysis.D: Added work function instead of subtracting

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Excellent MCQ: 4 options, 5 concepts, strong distractors

ASSESS_CHEM_ORG_001.subject: Chemistry
ASSESS_CHEM_ORG_001.question_text: In the compound CH₃-CH=CH-C≡CH, what is the total number of sigma (σ) and pi (π) bonds?
ASSESS_CHEM_ORG_001.question_text_html: In the compound CH₃-CH=CH-C≡CH, what is the total number of sigma (σ) and pi (π) bonds?
ASSESS_CHEM_ORG_001.solution_text: Structure: CH₃-CH=CH-C≡CH. Count σ bonds: 4 C-C σ bonds (including σ in double and triple bonds) + 6 C-H bonds = 10 σ bonds. Count π bonds: 1 in C=C + 2 in C≡C = 3 π bonds. Total: 10 σ and 3 π.

solution_steps.description: Draw complete structure with all hydrogens

solution_steps.explanation: Every single bond is σ. Every multiple bond has one σ

solution_steps.calculation: C-C σ bonds: 4 (1 single + 1 from double + 1 single + 1 from triple). C-H bonds: 6. Total σ = 4 + 6 = 10
solution_steps.explanation: Count all C-C σ bonds (every C-C connection has one σ) and all C-H bonds

ASSESS_CHEM_ORG_001.validation_notes: Gemini validated. Corrected solution explanation for bond counting

common_mistakes: Forgetting σ bonds in multiple bonds
metadata.hint: Draw complete structure. Count all single bonds + σ in multiple bonds. Then count π separately
metadata.key_insight: Tests understanding of bond types in organic molecules
metadata.elimination_strategy: 5 carbons in chain = 4 C-C bonds minimum. Each has at least 1 σ. Plus C-H bonds. Helps estimate.

ASSESS_CHEM_ORG_001.image_description: Structural formula of CH₃-CH=CH-C≡CH showing all bonds and atoms clearly with proper bond notation
ASSESS_CHEM_ORG_001.image_alt_text: Organic compound with single, double, and triple bonds
ASSESS_CHEM_ORG_001.diagram_code_python: import matplotlib.pyplot as plt; import numpy as np; fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1, figsize=(10, 5)); ax.set_xlim(-1, 11); ax.set_ylim(-1.5, 1.5); ax.set_aspect('equal'); c_positions = [(0, 0), (2, 0), (4, 0), (6, 0), (8, 0)]; [ax.plot(x, y, 'o', markersize=18, color='#6B46C1', zorder=3) or ax.text(x, y, 'C', fontsize=14, ha='center', va='center', color='white', fontweight='bold', zorder=4) for i, (x, y) in enumerate(c_positions)]; ax.plot([c_positions[0][0], c_positions[1][0]], [c_positions[0][1], c_positions[1][1]], 'k-', linewidth=3, zorder=1); ax.plot([c_positions[1][0], c_positions[2][0]], [c_positions[1][1], c_positions[2][1]], 'k-', linewidth=3, zorder=1); ax.plot([c_positions[1][0], c_positions[2][0]], [c_positions[1][1]+0.15, c_positions[2][1]+0.15], 'k-', linewidth=3, zorder=1); ax.plot([c_positions[2][0], c_positions[3][0]], [c_positions[2][1], c_positions[3][1]], 'k-', linewidth=3, zorder=1); ax.plot([c_positions[3][0], c_positions[4][0]], [c_positions[3][1], c_positions[4][1]], 'k-', linewidth=3, zorder=1); ax.plot([c_positions[3][0], c_positions[4][0]], [c_positions[3][1]+0.15, c_positions[4][1]+0.15], 'k-', linewidth=3, zorder=1); ax.plot([c_positions[3][0], c_positions[4][0]], [c_positions[3][1]-0.15, c_positions[4][1]-0.15], 'k-', linewidth=3, zorder=1); h_positions = [(0, -0.8), (0, 0.8), (-0.8, 0), (2, -0.8), (2, 0.8), (4, 0.8), (8, 0.8)]; [ax.text(x, y, 'H', fontsize=12, ha='center', va='center', color='#D946EF', fontweight='bold') for x, y in h_positions]; [ax.plot([min(c_positions, key=lambda p: np.sqrt((p[0]-x)**2 + (p[1]-y)**2))[0], x], [min(c_positions, key=lambda p: np.sqrt((p[0]-x)**2 + (p[1]-y)**2))[1], y], 'k-', linewidth=1.5, alpha=0.6) for x, y in h_positions[:6]]; ax.plot([8, 8], [0, 0.8], 'k-', linewidth=1.5, alpha=0.6); ax.text(1, -1.3, 'CH₃', fontsize=13, ha='center', bbox=dict(boxstyle='round', facecolor='#E9D5FF', alpha=0.7)); ax.text(3, -1.3, 'C=C', fontsize=13, ha='center', bbox=dict(boxstyle='round', facecolor='#FDE68A', alpha=0.7)); ax.text(7, -1.3, 'C≡C', fontsize=11, ha='center', bbox=dict(boxstyle='round', facecolor='#FECACA', alpha=0.7)); ax.text(5, 1.2, '10 σ bonds, 3 π bonds', fontsize=12, ha='center', fontweight='bold', bbox=dict(boxstyle='round', facecolor='white', edgecolor='#6B46C1', linewidth=2)); ax.axis('off'); ax.set_title('CH₃-CH=CH-C≡C-H Structure', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=15); plt.tight_layout(); plt.savefig('output.svg', format='svg', bbox_inches='tight'); plt.close()

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Good MCQ: 4 options with quality distractors

ASSESS_CHEM_ORG_002.subject: Chemistry
ASSESS_CHEM_ORG_002.question_text: A primary alkyl halide undergoes SN2 reaction with hydroxide ion with a rate constant of 2.5 × 10⁻³ M⁻¹s⁻¹. If the concentration of alkyl halide is 0.1 M and OH⁻ is 0.2 M, calculate the initial rate of reaction in M/s. Express in scientific notation as X × 10⁻⁵.
ASSESS_CHEM_ORG_002.question_text_html: A primary alkyl halide undergoes SN2 reaction with hydroxide ion with a rate constant of 2.5 × 10⁻³ M⁻¹s⁻¹. If the concentration of alkyl halide is 0.1 M and OH⁻ is 0.2 M, calculate the initial rate of reaction in M/s. Express in scientific notation as X × 10⁻⁵.
ASSESS_CHEM_ORG_002.solution_text: For SN2 reaction: Rate = k[RX][OH⁻] = (2.5×10⁻³)(0.1)(0.2) = 5×10⁻⁵ M/s. Express as 5 × 10⁻⁵

solution_steps.explanation: SN2 is second order - depends on both substrate and nucleophile
Plug in all given concentrations and rate constant

metadata.hint: SN2 is second order. Rate depends on both reactants
metadata.key_insight: Tests understanding of SN2 kinetics and numerical calculation

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Moderate numerical: 3 steps, 2 concepts

ASSESS_CHEM_ORG_003.subject: Chemistry
ASSESS_CHEM_ORG_003.question_text: Arrange the following compounds in order of increasing acidity: (I) CH₃CH₂COOH, (II) ClCH₂CH₂COOH, (III) Cl₂CHCH₂COOH, (IV) Cl₃CCH₂COOH
ASSESS_CHEM_ORG_003.question_text_html:
Arrange the following compounds in order of increasing acidity:
(I) CH₃CH₂COOH
(II) ClCH₂CH₂COOH
(III) Cl₂CHCH₂COOH
(IV) Cl₃CCH₂COOH
ASSESS_CHEM_ORG_003.solution_text: Chlorine is electron-withdrawing (-I effect), stabilizes conjugate base, increases acidity. More Cl atoms = stronger -I effect = more acidic. Order: CH₃CH₂COOH (no Cl) < ClCH₂CH₂COOH (1 Cl) < Cl₂CHCH₂COOH (2 Cl) < Cl₃CCH₂COOH (3 Cl). Answer: I < II < III < IV

solution_steps.calculation: Count Cl atoms: I(0), II(1), III(2), IV(3)
solution_steps.explanation: Chlorine withdraws electrons through inductive effect
EWG stabilizes conjugate base (COO⁻), making acid stronger
Direct correlation between Cl count and acidity

metadata.hint: Count Cl atoms. More Cl = stronger -I effect = more acidic
metadata.key_insight: High discrimination - tests understanding of electron effects on acidity
metadata.elimination_strategy: IV has most Cl, must be most acidic. I has no Cl, must be least acidic. Narrows to A or D.

distractor_analysis.C: Wrong position of II and III

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Good MCQ: 4 options with quality distractors

ASSESS_CHEM_PHY_001.subject: Chemistry
ASSESS_CHEM_PHY_001.question_text: Given: C(s) + O₂(g) → CO₂(g), ΔH = -394 kJ/mol and H₂(g) + ½O₂(g) → H₂O(l), ΔH = -286 kJ/mol. If the enthalpy of combustion of CH₄(g) is -890 kJ/mol, calculate the enthalpy of formation of CH₄(g) in kJ/mol. (Take absolute value)
ASSESS_CHEM_PHY_001.question_text_html: Given: C(s) + O₂(g) → CO₂(g), ΔH = -394 kJ/mol and H₂(g) + ½O₂(g) → H₂O(l), ΔH = -286 kJ/mol. If the enthalpy of combustion of CH₄(g) is -890 kJ/mol, calculate the enthalpy of formation of CH₄(g) in kJ/mol. (Take absolute value)
ASSESS_CHEM_PHY_001.solution_text: Combustion: CH₄ + 2O₂ → CO₂ + 2H₂O, ΔH = -890. Formation: C + 2H₂ → CH₄, ΔH_f = ? Using Hess's law: ΔH_combustion = ΔH_f(products) - ΔH_f(reactants). -890 = (-394 + 2×(-286)) - ΔH_f(CH₄). -890 = -966 - ΔH_f(CH₄). ΔH_f(CH₄) = -966 + 890 = -76 kJ/mol. Absolute value = 76

solution_steps.explanation: ΔH_f of elements in standard state = 0

ASSESS_CHEM_PHY_001.jee_pattern: Standard thermodynamics calculation with Hess's law
ASSESS_CHEM_PHY_001.validation_notes: Gemini validated. Corrected answer from 75 to 76 kJ/mol

metadata.hint: Use Hess's law. Remember ΔH_f of O₂ = 0. Don't forget the factor of 2 for H₂O
metadata.key_insight: Tests application of Hess's law to calculate unknown enthalpy

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Multi-step numerical: 4 steps, 2 concepts

ASSESS_CHEM_PHY_002.subject: Chemistry
ASSESS_CHEM_PHY_002.question_text: For the reaction N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g), Kc = 0.5 at a certain temperature. Calculate Kp if the temperature is 400 K. (R = 0.082 L·atm·K⁻¹·mol⁻¹). Express your answer as X × 10⁻⁴.
ASSESS_CHEM_PHY_002.question_text_html: For the reaction N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g), Kc = 0.5 at a certain temperature. Calculate Kp if the temperature is 400 K. (R = 0.082 L·atm·K⁻¹·mol⁻¹). Express your answer as X × 10⁻⁴.
ASSESS_CHEM_PHY_002.solution_text: Δn = (moles of gaseous products) - (moles of gaseous reactants) = 2 - (1+3) = -2. Kp = Kc(RT)^Δn = 0.5(0.082×400)^(-2) = 0.5/(32.8)² = 0.5/1075.84 = 4.65×10⁻⁴

metadata.hint: Calculate Δn first. Remember Δn = (products) - (reactants) for gases only
metadata.key_insight: Tests understanding of relationship between Kp and Kc

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Multi-step numerical: 4 steps, 2 concepts

ASSESS_CHEM_PHY_003.subject: Chemistry
ASSESS_CHEM_PHY_003.question_text: For the cell Zn|Zn²⁺(0.1M)||Cu²⁺(0.01M)|Cu, E°(Zn²⁺/Zn) = -0.76 V and E°(Cu²⁺/Cu) = +0.34 V. What is the cell potential at 25°C? (2.303RT/F = 0.059 V)
ASSESS_CHEM_PHY_003.question_text_html: For the cell Zn|Zn²⁺(0.1M)||Cu²⁺(0.01M)|Cu, E°(Zn²⁺/Zn) = -0.76 V and E°(Cu²⁺/Cu) = +0.34 V. What is the cell potential at 25°C? (2.303RT/F = 0.059 V)

solution_steps.explanation: Cu is reduced (cathode), Zn is oxidized (anode)

solution_steps.description: Write cell reaction and identify n
solution_steps.explanation: Both Zn and Cu involve 2 electrons

metadata.formula_used: E°_cell = E°_cathode - E°_anode, Nernst: E = E° - (0.059/n)log(Q)
metadata.hint: First find E°_cell. Then apply Nernst equation with Q = [Zn²⁺]/[Cu²⁺]
metadata.key_insight: Tests Nernst equation application with concentration effects
metadata.elimination_strategy: E° = 1.10 V. Concentration changes will alter this slightly. Helps narrow choices.

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Excellent MCQ: 4 options, 3 concepts, strong distractors

ASSESS_CHEM_PHY_004.subject: Chemistry
ASSESS_CHEM_PHY_004.question_text: A first-order reaction has a half-life of 20 minutes. Calculate the rate constant in min⁻¹. Express your answer as X × 10⁻².
ASSESS_CHEM_PHY_004.question_text_html: A first-order reaction has a half-life of 20 minutes. Calculate the rate constant in min⁻¹. Express your answer as X × 10⁻².
ASSESS_CHEM_PHY_004.solution_text: For first order: t₁/₂ = 0.693/k. Therefore k = 0.693/t₁/₂ = 0.693/20 = 0.03465 min⁻¹ = 3.47 × 10⁻² min⁻¹

solution_steps.explanation: For first order, half-life is independent of concentration

metadata.hint: For first order: t₁/₂ = 0.693/k. Rearrange and solve
metadata.key_insight: Tests understanding of first-order kinetics and half-life relationship

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Multi-step numerical: 4 steps, 2 concepts

ASSESS_CHEM_INORG_001.subject: Chemistry
ASSESS_CHEM_INORG_001.question_text: Which of the following elements has the highest first ionization energy?
ASSESS_CHEM_INORG_001.question_text_html: Which of the following elements has the highest first ionization energy?
ASSESS_CHEM_INORG_001.solution_text: Ionization energy increases left to right across a period (increasing nuclear charge) and decreases down a group. Noble gases have highest IE in their period due to stable filled shell. Among N, O, F, Ne - all in period 2 - Ne has highest IE. Note: N has higher IE than O due to half-filled stability.

solution_steps.explanation: IE generally increases left to right, decreases top to bottom
Noble gas has completely filled stable configuration
Noble gases require most energy to remove electron due to stability

metadata.formula_used: IE trend: increases → across period, decreases ↓ down group
common_mistakes: Thinking F has highest (forgetting noble gas)
metadata.hint: Noble gases have highest IE in their period due to filled shell stability
metadata.key_insight: Tests understanding of periodic trends and stability
metadata.elimination_strategy: Noble gases are most stable. Ne should have highest IE among these.

distractor_analysis.A: N has half-filled stability but not as high as Ne
distractor_analysis.B: O has lower IE than N due to electron repulsion
distractor_analysis.C: F has high IE but less than noble gas

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Good MCQ: 4 options with quality distractors

ASSESS_CHEM_INORG_002.subject: Chemistry
ASSESS_CHEM_INORG_002.question_text: Calculate the bond order of O₂⁺ ion using molecular orbital theory. Express as a decimal (e.g., 2.5).
ASSESS_CHEM_INORG_002.question_text_html: Calculate the bond order of O₂⁺ ion using molecular orbital theory. Express as a decimal (e.g., 2.5).
ASSESS_CHEM_INORG_002.solution_text: O₂ has 16 electrons. O₂⁺ has 15 electrons. MO configuration: σ1s² σ*1s² σ2s² σ*2s² σ2p_z² π2p_x² π2p_y² π*2p_x¹. Bonding electrons = 10, Antibonding = 5. Bond order = (10-5)/2 = 2.5

solution_steps.calculation: O₂ has 16 electrons, O₂⁺ has 15 electrons (lost one)

solution_steps.formula: σ1s² σ*1s² σ2s² σ*2s² σ2p² π2p⁴ π*2p¹
solution_steps.explanation: Electron removed from π* antibonding orbital
Sum electrons in bonding and antibonding orbitals

metadata.hint: O₂⁺ has 15 electrons. Fill MOs. Count bonding and antibonding electrons
metadata.key_insight: Tests MOT application to ions

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Multi-step numerical: 4 steps, 2 concepts

ASSESS_CHEM_INORG_003.subject: Chemistry
ASSESS_CHEM_INORG_003.question_text: What is the geometry and hybridization of [Ni(CN)₄]²⁻ complex? (Ni²⁺ is d⁸, CN⁻ is strong field ligand)
ASSESS_CHEM_INORG_003.question_text_html: What is the geometry and hybridization of [Ni(CN)₄]²⁻ complex? (Ni²⁺ is d⁸, CN⁻ is strong field ligand)
ASSESS_CHEM_INORG_003.solution_text: Ni²⁺ is d⁸. CN⁻ is strong field ligand causing pairing. Electronic config after pairing: d_xy², d_xz², d_yz², d_z²⁰, d_x²-y²⁰. Four vacant orbitals (d_x²-y², s, p_x, p_y) form dsp² hybrid orbitals. Four CN⁻ ligands give square planar geometry.

solution_steps.calculation: CN⁻ is strong field → causes pairing
solution_steps.explanation: Strong field ligands cause electron pairing
One d, one s, two p orbitals
dsp² hybridization gives square planar geometry

ASSESS_CHEM_INORG_003.jee_pattern: Geometry and hybridization of coordination compounds

metadata.hint: CN⁻ is strong field. Causes pairing in d⁸. Four ligands with paired d⁸ gives dsp² = square planar
metadata.key_insight: Tests understanding of ligand field effects and geometry prediction
metadata.elimination_strategy: Strong field with d⁸ typically gives square planar, not tetrahedral. Eliminates A.

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Good MCQ: 4 options with quality distractors

ASSESS_MATH_CALC_001.subject: Mathematics
ASSESS_MATH_CALC_001.solution_text: Direct substitution gives 0/0 form. Apply L'Hopital's rule three times. First: [3cos(3x)-3]/(3x²), still 0/0. Second: [-9sin(3x)]/(6x), still 0/0. Third: [-27cos(3x)]/6 = -27/6 = -9/2

metadata.formula_used: L'Hopital's rule: lim f(x)/g(x) = lim f'(x)/g'(x) when 0/0
metadata.hint: 0/0 form requires L'Hopital. May need to apply multiple times
metadata.key_insight: High discrimination - tests repeated application of L'Hopital's rule
metadata.elimination_strategy: Numerator is negative for small positive x (sin(3x) < 3x), denominator positive, so limit negative

distractor_analysis.B: Correct numerator but forgot to simplify -27/6
distractor_analysis.C: Stopped at first 0/0 without applying L'Hopital
distractor_analysis.D: Gave up thinking limit doesn't exist

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Excellent MCQ: 4 options, 3 concepts, strong distractors

ASSESS_MATH_CALC_002.subject: Mathematics
ASSESS_MATH_CALC_002.question_text: The radius of a circular oil spill increases at a rate of 2 m/min. Find the rate at which the area is increasing when the radius is 10 m. Express your answer in m²/min.
ASSESS_MATH_CALC_002.question_text_html: The radius of a circular oil spill increases at a rate of 2 m/min. Find the rate at which the area is increasing when the radius is 10 m. Express your answer in m²/min.
ASSESS_MATH_CALC_002.solution_text: A = πr². Given dr/dt = 2 m/min. Need dA/dt when r=10. dA/dt = dA/dr × dr/dt = 2πr × dr/dt = 2π(10) × 2 = 40π ≈ 125.66 m²/min

solution_steps.explanation: Area of circle in terms of radius

metadata.hint: Use chain rule: dA/dt = (dA/dr)(dr/dt)
metadata.key_insight: Tests understanding of related rates and chain rule application

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Multi-step numerical: 4 steps, 2 concepts

ASSESS_MATH_CALC_003.question_text_html: Find the maximum value of the function f(x) = x³ - 3x² - 9x + 5 on the interval [-2, 4].

solution_steps.description: Check if critical points are in interval
Evaluate function at critical points and endpoints
solution_steps.explanation: Evaluate function at all critical points and endpoints

ASSESS_MATH_CALC_003.validation_notes: Gemini validated. Corrected answer from C to A (10)

metadata.formula_used: f'(x)=0 for critical points, check endpoints
metadata.hint: Find critical points, evaluate f at critical points AND endpoints

ASSESS_MATH_CALC_004.question_text_html: Evaluate the definite integral: ∫02 (x² + 2x) dx. Express your answer as a decimal.

ASSESS_MATH_ALG_001.subject: Mathematics
ASSESS_MATH_ALG_001.question_text: If α and β are roots of the equation 2x² - 5x + 3 = 0, find the value of α² + β².
ASSESS_MATH_ALG_001.question_text_html: If α and β are roots of the equation 2x² - 5x + 3 = 0, find the value of α² + β².
ASSESS_MATH_ALG_001.solution_text: Sum of roots: α+β = 5/2. Product of roots: αβ = 3/2. Using α²+β² = (α+β)² - 2αβ = (5/2)² - 2(3/2) = 25/4 - 6/2 = 25/4 - 12/4 = 13/4

solution_steps.description: Find sum and product of roots

metadata.hint: Use Vieta's formulas for sum and product, then identity for sum of squares
metadata.key_insight: Tests Vieta's formulas and algebraic manipulation - high discrimination
metadata.elimination_strategy: (α+β)²=25/4. Answer must be less than this since we subtract 2αβ>0. Eliminates A.

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Excellent MCQ: 4 options, 2 concepts, strong distractors

ASSESS_MATH_ALG_002.subject: Mathematics
ASSESS_MATH_ALG_002.question_text: Find the sum of the infinite geometric series: 8 + 4 + 2 + 1 + ...
ASSESS_MATH_ALG_002.question_text_html: Find the sum of the infinite geometric series: 8 + 4 + 2 + 1 + ...
ASSESS_MATH_ALG_002.solution_text: First term a=8, common ratio r=4/8=1/2. For |r|<1, sum to infinity S=a/(1-r) = 8/(1-0.5) = 8/0.5 = 16

solution_steps.description: Identify first term and common ratio
solution_steps.explanation: First term and ratio between consecutive terms

metadata.hint: Find common ratio first. Check |r|<1. Then use infinite GP sum formula
metadata.key_insight: Tests understanding of infinite GP convergence and sum formula

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Multi-step numerical: 4 steps, 3 concepts

ASSESS_MATH_ALG_003.subject: Mathematics
ASSESS_MATH_ALG_003.question_text: If z = 1 + i√3, find the principal argument of z.
ASSESS_MATH_ALG_003.question_text_html: If z = 1 + i√3, find the principal argument of z.
ASSESS_MATH_ALG_003.solution_text: z = 1 + i√3 is in first quadrant (both parts positive). arg(z) = tan⁻¹(Im/Re) = tan⁻¹(√3/1) = tan⁻¹(√3) = π/3 (60°)

solution_steps.explanation: Complex number is in first quadrant
Standard argument formula for first quadrant

metadata.hint: Calculate tan⁻¹(imaginary/real). Recognize standard angle
metadata.key_insight: Tests complex number argument and knowledge of standard angles
metadata.elimination_strategy: tan(π/6)=1/√3, tan(π/4)=1, tan(π/3)=√3. Since ratio is √3, answer is π/3.

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Excellent MCQ: 4 options, 2 concepts, strong distractors

solution_steps.formula: n trials, k successes, probability p

ASSESS_MATH_COORD_001.subject: Mathematics
ASSESS_MATH_COORD_001.question_text: Find the equation of the tangent to the circle x² + y² = 25 at the point (3, 4).
ASSESS_MATH_COORD_001.question_text_html: Find the equation of the tangent to the circle x² + y² = 25 at the point (3, 4).
ASSESS_MATH_COORD_001.solution_text: For circle x²+y²=r², tangent at (x₁,y₁) is xx₁+yy₁=r². Here (x₁,y₁)=(3,4) and r²=25. Tangent: 3x+4y=25

solution_steps.explanation: Standard form circle centered at origin
Standard formula for tangent to circle

ASSESS_MATH_COORD_001.jee_pattern: Tangent to circle at given point

metadata.hint: For circle x²+y²=r², tangent at (x₁,y₁) is xx₁+yy₁=r²
metadata.key_insight: Tests knowledge of tangent formula for circle
metadata.elimination_strategy: Point (3,4) must satisfy tangent equation. Plug in to verify: only A works.

distractor_analysis.B: Swapped coefficients of x and y

ASSESS_MATH_COORD_001.image_description: Circle centered at origin with radius 5, showing point (3,4) on the circle and the tangent line at that point
ASSESS_MATH_COORD_001.diagram_code_python: import matplotlib.pyplot as plt; import numpy as np; fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1, figsize=(8, 8)); ax.set_xlim(-7, 7); ax.set_ylim(-7, 7); ax.set_aspect('equal'); theta = np.linspace(0, 2*np.pi, 200); x_circle = 5 * np.cos(theta); y_circle = 5 * np.sin(theta); ax.plot(x_circle, y_circle, linewidth=3, color='#6B46C1', label='x² + y² = 25'); ax.plot([3], [4], 'ro', markersize=12, label='Point (3, 4)', zorder=5); x_tangent = np.linspace(-2, 7, 100); y_tangent = (25 - 3*x_tangent) / 4; ax.plot(x_tangent, y_tangent, linewidth=2.5, color='#D946EF', linestyle='--', label='Tangent: 3x + 4y = 25'); ax.plot([0, 3], [0, 4], 'g--', linewidth=2, alpha=0.7, label='Radius'); ax.plot([0], [0], 'ko', markersize=10, label='Center O(0,0)'); ax.text(1.5, 2.5, 'r = 5', fontsize=12, color='green', fontweight='bold', bbox=dict(boxstyle='round', facecolor='white', alpha=0.8)); ax.text(5, 5.5, '3x + 4y = 25', fontsize=12, color='#D946EF', fontweight='bold', bbox=dict(boxstyle='round', facecolor='#FDE68A', alpha=0.8)); ax.grid(True, alpha=0.3, linestyle='--'); ax.axhline(y=0, color='k', linewidth=0.5); ax.axvline(x=0, color='k', linewidth=0.5); ax.legend(loc='upper left', fontsize=10); ax.set_xlabel('x', fontsize=12); ax.set_ylabel('y', fontsize=12); ax.set_title('Circle x² + y² = 25 with Tangent at (3, 4)', fontsize=13, fontweight='bold', pad=15); plt.tight_layout(); plt.savefig('output.svg', format='svg', bbox_inches='tight'); plt.close()

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Excellent MCQ: 4 options, 3 concepts, strong distractors

ASSESS_MATH_COORD_002.subject: Mathematics
ASSESS_MATH_COORD_002.question_text: Find the distance of the point (3, 8) from the focus of the parabola x² = 16y.
ASSESS_MATH_COORD_002.question_text_html: Find the distance of the point (3, 8) from the focus of the parabola x² = 16y.
ASSESS_MATH_COORD_002.solution_text: For x²=4ay, focus is at (0,a). Here 4a=16, so a=4. Focus is at (0,4). Distance from (3,8) to (0,4) = √[(3-0)²+(8-4)²] = √[9+16] = √25 = 5

solution_steps.explanation: For parabola opening upward, focus on y-axis

ASSESS_MATH_COORD_002.validation_notes: Gemini validated. Corrected parabola equation from y²=16x to x²=16y

metadata.hint: Find focus from parabola equation first, then use distance formula
metadata.key_insight: Tests parabola properties and distance calculation

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Multi-step numerical: 4 steps, 3 concepts
